message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Set Propagation Techniques for Reachability Analysis
Paper Abstract: Reachability analysis consists in computing the set of states that are reachable by a dynamical system from all initial states and for all admissible inputs and parameters. It is a fundamental problem motivated by many applications in formal verification, controller synthesis, and estimation, to name only a few. This article focuses on a class of methods for computing a guaranteed overapproximation of the reachable set of continuous and hybrid systems, relying predominantly on set propagation; starting from the set of initial states, these techniques iteratively propagate a sequence of sets according to the system dynamics. After a review of set representation and computation, the article presents the state of the art of set propagation techniques for reachability analysis of linear, nonlinear, and hybrid systems. It ends with a discussion of successful applications of reachability analysis to real-world problems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Overview

The term "linear systems" can refer to several different concepts:

### Systems Theory
In systems theory, a linear system is a mathematical model of a system based on the use of a linear operator.(no content)Linear systems typically exhibit features and properties that are much simpler than the nonlinear case.

### Systems of Linear Equations
In mathematics, a system of linear equations (or linear system) is a collection of two or more linear equations involving the same variables.(no content)A solution to a linear system is an assignment of values to the variables such that all the equations are simultaneously satisfied.(no content)Linear systems are a fundamental part of linear algebra, a subject used in most modern mathematics, and computational algorithms for finding the solutions are an important part of numerical linear algebra, playing a prominent role in engineering, physics, chemistry, computer science, and economics.

### Linear Time-Invariant Systems
In system analysis, among other fields of study, a linear time-invariant (LTI) system is a system that produces an output signal from any input signal subject to the constraints of linearity and time-invariance.(no content)LTI system theory is an area of applied mathematics which has direct applications in electrical circuit analysis and design, signal processing and filter design, control theory, mechanical engineering, image processing, the design of measuring instruments of many sorts, and many other technical areas.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of hybrid systems:

## General Definition

A hybrid system is a dynamical system that exhibits both continuous and discrete dynamic behavior – a system that can both flow (described by a differential equation) and jump (described by a state machine, automaton, or a difference equation).

## Key Applications

The term "hybrid systems" applies to many different domains:

**Dynamical Systems:** In automata theory, a hybrid automaton is a mathematical model for precisely describing hybrid systems, for instance systems in which digital computational processes interact with analog physical processes.

**Renewable Energy:** Hybrid systems, as the name implies, combine two or more modes of electricity generation together, usually using renewable technologies such as solar photovoltaic (PV) and wind turbines.

**Vehicle Powertrains:** A hybrid vehicle has multiple forms of motive power, and can come in many configurations. This includes both electric and internal combustion engine combinations.

**Building Construction:** Hybrid masonry is a new type of building system that uses engineered, reinforced masonry to brace frame structures. Typically, hybrid masonry is implemented with concrete masonry panels used to brace steel frame structures.

**Artificial Intelligence:** Hybrid intelligent system denotes a software system which employs, in parallel, a combination of methods and techniques from artificial intelligence subfields.

The common theme across all these applications is the combination of different technologies or methods to achieve improved performance or functionality.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Controller synthesis"

Links: [{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"Supervisory control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supervisory_control_theory"},{"title":"Digital control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_control"},{"title":"Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Syntorial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntorial"},{"title":"Ribbon controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ribbon_controller"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Synthesizer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Synthesizer"},{"title":"Modular synthesizer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_synthesis"},{"title":"Continuum Fingerboard - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuum_Fingerboard"}]

Based on the search results, I found information about **controller synthesis** in the context of control theory:

## Overview

H-infinity ("H∞") methods are used in control theory to synthesize controllers to achieve stabilization with guaranteed performance.(no content)To use H∞ methods, a control designer expresses the control problem as a mathematical optimization problem and then finds the controller that solves this optimization.

## Related Approaches

In addition to H∞ methods, there are other controller synthesis approaches:

- Supervisory control theory (SCT), also known as the Ramadge–Wonham framework, is a method for automatically synthesizing supervisors that restrict the behavior of a plant such that as much as possible of the given specifications are fulfilled.

- Recent research focuses on the synthesis of optimal distributed controllers, which optimizes a certain H-infinity or the H₂ control criterion.

## Key Characteristics

H∞ techniques have the advantage over classical control techniques in that H∞ techniques are readily applicable to problems involving multivariate systems with cross-coupling between channels; disadvantages of H∞ techniques include the level of mathematical understanding needed to apply them successfully and the need for a reasonably good model of the system to be controlled.

Controller synthesis is a fundamental aspect of control engineering, aimed at designing controllers that meet specific performance and stability requirements for dynamic systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Nonlinear systems"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Category:Nonlinear systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Nonlinear_systems"},{"title":"Nonlinear system identification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system_identification"},{"title":"Non-Linear Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Linear_Systems"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Linear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_system"},{"title":"Linear stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_stability"},{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Limit cycle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limit_cycle"}]

Here are the search results for "Nonlinear systems":

## Overview

A nonlinear system is defined as any system that is not linear, that is any system that does not satisfy the superposition principle.(no content)Less technically, a nonlinear system is any problem where the variable(s) to solve for cannot be written as a linear sum of independent components.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear systems do not follow the principle of superposition (linearity and homogeneity), may have multiple isolated equilibrium points, and may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, and chaos.

## Differential Equations

A system of differential equations is said to be nonlinear if it is not a system of linear equations. Problems involving nonlinear differential equations are extremely diverse, and methods of solution or analysis are problem dependent.(no content)Examples of nonlinear differential equations are the Navier–Stokes equations in fluid dynamics and the Lotka–Volterra equations in biology.

## Challenges in Analysis

One of the greatest difficulties of nonlinear problems is that it is not generally possible to combine known solutions into new solutions.(no content)The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems.

## Chaotic Behavior

Simple nonlinear dynamical systems, including piecewise linear systems, can exhibit strongly unpredictable behavior, which might seem to be random, despite the fact that they are fundamentally deterministic. This unpredictable behavior has been called chaos.

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Category:Nonlinear systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Nonlinear_systems"},{"title":"Nonlinear system identification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system_identification"},{"title":"Non-Linear Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Linear_Systems"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Linear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_system"},{"title":"Linear stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_stability"},{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Limit cycle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limit_cycle"}]

Here are the search results for "Nonlinear systems":

## Overview

A nonlinear system is defined as any system that is not linear, that is any system that does not satisfy the superposition principle.(no content)Less technically, a nonlinear system is any problem where the variable(s) to solve for cannot be written as a linear sum of independent components.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear systems do not follow the principle of superposition (linearity and homogeneity), may have multiple isolated equilibrium points, and may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, and chaos.

## Differential Equations

A system of differential equations is said to be nonlinear if it is not a system of linear equations. Problems involving nonlinear differential equations are extremely diverse, and methods of solution or analysis are problem dependent.(no content)Examples of nonlinear differential equations are the Navier–Stokes equations in fluid dynamics and the Lotka–Volterra equations in biology.

## Challenges in Analysis

One of the greatest difficulties of nonlinear problems is that it is not generally possible to combine known solutions into new solutions.(no content)The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems.

## Chaotic Behavior

Simple nonlinear dynamical systems, including piecewise linear systems, can exhibit strongly unpredictable behavior, which might seem to be random, despite the fact that they are fundamentally deterministic. This unpredictable behavior has been called chaos.

Web search results for query: "Dynamical systems"

Links: [{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Projected dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Projected_dynamical_system"},{"title":"Category:Dynamical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Dynamical_systems"},{"title":"Crisis (dynamical systems) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crisis_(dynamical_systems)"},{"title":"Ergodic Theory and Dynamical Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_Theory_and_Dynamical_Systems"},{"title":"Sequential dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequential_dynamical_system"},{"title":"Category:Theorems in dynamical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Theorems_in_dynamical_systems"},{"title":"Conley's fundamental theorem of dynamical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conley's_fundamental_theorem_of_dynamical_systems"},{"title":"Normal form (dynamical systems) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_form_(dynamical_systems)"}]

Here's what I found about dynamical systems:

## Definition

A dynamical system is a system in which a function describes the time dependence of a point in an ambient space, such as in a parametric curve.(no content)A dynamical system has a state determined by a collection of real numbers, or more generally by a set of points in an appropriate state space.

## Examples

Examples include the mathematical models that describe the swinging of a clock pendulum, the flow of water in a pipe, the random motion of particles in the air, and the number of fish each springtime in a lake.

## Types of Dynamical Systems

When differential equations are employed, the theory is called continuous dynamical systems.(no content)When difference equations are employed, the theory is called discrete dynamical systems.

## Key Focus Areas

This theory deals with the long-term qualitative behavior of dynamical systems, and studies the nature of, and when possible the solutions of, the equations of motion of systems that are often primarily mechanical or otherwise physical in nature, such as planetary orbits and the behaviour of electronic circuits, as well as systems that arise in biology, economics, and elsewhere.(no content)The focus is not on finding precise solutions to the equations defining the dynamical system (which is often hopeless), but rather to answer questions like "Will the system settle down to a steady state in the long term, and if so, what are the possible steady states?", or "Does the long-term behavior of the system depend on its initial condition?"

## Applications

The study of dynamical systems has applications to a wide variety of fields such as mathematics, physics, biology, chemistry, engineering, economics, history, and medicine.

Links: [{"title":"Estimation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estimation_theory"},{"title":"Talk:Estimation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Estimation_theory"},{"title":"Category:Estimation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Estimation_theory"},{"title":"Estimator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estimator"},{"title":"Multidimensional spectral estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multidimensional_spectral_estimation"},{"title":"Mark Pinsker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Pinsker"},{"title":"Maximum likelihood estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_likelihood_estimation"},{"title":"Joseph Tabrikian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Tabrikian"},{"title":"Extreme risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extreme_risks"},{"title":"Minimum-variance unbiased estimator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum-variance_unbiased_estimator"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of estimation theory:

## Definition

Estimation theory is a branch of statistics that deals with estimating the values of parameters based on measured empirical data that has a random component.(no content)The parameters describe an underlying physical setting in such a way that their value affects the distribution of the measured data.

## Core Concepts

Measured data are likely to be subject to noise or uncertainty and it is through statistical probability that optimal solutions are sought to extract as much information from the data as possible.(no content)Estimation theory is concerned with the properties of estimators; that is, with defining properties that can be used to compare different estimators (different rules for creating estimates) for the same quantity, based on the same data.

## Types of Estimators

When the word "estimator" is used without a qualifier, it usually refers to point estimation. The estimate in this case is a single point in the parameter space.(no content)There also exists another type of estimator: interval estimators, where the estimates are subsets of the parameter space.

## Applications

Numerous fields require the use of estimation theory. For example, in radar the aim is to find the range of objects (airplanes, boats, etc.) by analyzing the two-way transit timing of received echoes of transmitted pulses. Since the reflected pulses are unavoidably embedded in electrical noise, their measured values are randomly distributed, so that the transit time must be estimated.

Here's what I found about formal verification:

## Definition

Formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

## How It Works

The verification of these systems is done by ensuring the existence of a formal proof of a mathematical model of the system. There are several main approaches:

1. **Model Checking**: Model checking involves a systematic and exhaustive exploration of the mathematical model, which is possible for finite models and some infinite models by using abstraction or symmetry, typically exploring all states and transitions using smart abstraction techniques.

2. **Deductive Verification**: This approach generates from the system and its specifications a collection of mathematical proof obligations, the truth of which imply conformance of the system to its specification, and discharges these obligations using proof assistants or automatic theorem provers, including SMT solvers.

## Applications

Formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing.(no content)Formal methods are applied in different areas including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels, with several examples where they have been used to verify the functionality of hardware and software used in data centres, such as IBM using ACL2 in the AMD x86 processor development.

Here's what I found about formal verification:

## Definition

Formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

## How It Works

The verification of these systems is done by ensuring the existence of a formal proof of a mathematical model of the system. There are several main approaches:

1. **Model Checking**: Model checking involves a systematic and exhaustive exploration of the mathematical model, which is possible for finite models and some infinite models by using abstraction or symmetry, typically exploring all states and transitions using smart abstraction techniques.

2. **Deductive Verification**: This approach generates from the system and its specifications a collection of mathematical proof obligations, the truth of which imply conformance of the system to its specification, and discharges these obligations using proof assistants or automatic theorem provers, including SMT solvers.

## Applications

Formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing.(no content)Formal methods are applied in different areas including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels, with several examples where they have been used to verify the functionality of hardware and software used in data centres, such as IBM using ACL2 in the AMD x86 processor development.

Based on the search results, "set propagation" can refer to several different concepts depending on the context:

## Computer Science & Logic

Unit propagation (UP) or boolean constraint propagation (BCP) is a procedure of automated theorem proving that can simplify a set of propositional clauses.(no content)The procedure is based on unit clauses that are composed of a single literal in conjunctive normal form.(no content)Unit propagation consists in removing every clause containing a unit clause's literal and in discarding the complement of a unit clause's literal from every clause containing that complement.

## Radio & Signal Propagation

Propagation graphs are a mathematical modelling method for radio propagation channels. A propagation graph is a signal flow graph in which vertices represent transmitters, receivers or scatterers. Edges in the graph model propagation conditions between vertices.

## Biology & Horticulture

Plant propagation is the process by which new plants grow from various sources, including seeds, cuttings, and other plant parts.

## Probability & Statistics

When f is a set of non-linear combination of the variables x, an interval propagation could be performed in order to compute intervals which contain all consistent values for the variables. This relates to propagation of uncertainty in measurements and calculations.

The most common technical usage of "set propagation" in computer science refers to unit propagation in logic and SAT solvers.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Reachability analysis"

Links: [{"title":"Reachability analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_analysis"},{"title":"Reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability"},{"title":"Reachability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_problem"},{"title":"Context-free language reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-free_language_reachability"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Petri net - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net"},{"title":"International Conference on Reachability Problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Reachability_Problems"},{"title":"Reaching definition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaching_definition"},{"title":"Petri net unfoldings - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net_unfoldings"},{"title":"Control-flow graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-flow_graph"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about reachability analysis:

## Overview

Reachability analysis is a solution to the reachability problem in the particular context of distributed systems, used to determine which global states can be reached by a distributed system consisting of a certain number of local entities that communicate by the exchange of messages.

## Results and Outputs

The result of reachability analysis is a global state transition graph (also called reachability graph) which shows all global states of the distributed system that are reachable from the initial global state, and all possible sequences of send, consume and service interactions performed by the local entities.(no content)The transition graph can be used for checking general design flaws of the protocol, but also for verifying that the sequences of service interactions by the entities correspond to the requirements given by the global service specification of the system.

## Key Challenges

One major challenge in reachability analysis is the "state space explosion" problem. A practical issue of reachability analysis is the so-called "state space explosion"—if two entities of a protocol have 100 states each and the medium may include 10 types of messages, up to two in each direction, the number of global states in the reachability graph is bound by 100 million.

## Tools

A number of tools have been developed to automatically perform reachability analysis and model checking on the reachability graph, including the SPIN model checker.

## Applications

Reachability analysis is used across multiple domains including distributed systems, formal verification, Petri nets, and program analysis.

Perfect! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was done:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey

The paper "Set Propagation Techniques for Reachability Analysis" is classified as a **survey** because it reviews the state of the art of existing set propagation techniques for reachability analysis, rather than proposing novel methods.

**Extracted Triples (9 total):**

1. **Reachability analysis** (task) - The core problem being analyzed
2. **Set propagation** (method) - The main technique reviewed for computing reachable sets
3. **Dynamical system** (concept) - The type of system for which reachability is being analyzed
4. **Hybrid system** (concept) - One class of systems addressed
5. **Linear system** (concept) - One class of systems addressed
6. **Nonlinear system** (concept) - One class of systems addressed
7. **Formal verification** (task) - A key application domain
8. **Control theory** (concept) - The theoretical foundation for controller synthesis
